Description: Analyse customer needs and specify clear requirements. Present the results of the needs study to the customer and ask for feedback. Make changes in the plans according to feedback.
Use the SMART technique to define a specific, measurable, and time-related scope. Ask the client if the scope is acceptable, and ask the management if it is realistic.
Before starting production, plan how the results will be tested. Provide structure for the tests, test goals, quality criteria, resources, and timeframe.
Schedule regular reviews of project progress, achievements, and challenges with stakeholders and the project team.
Use prioritisation to allocate resources for more valuable tasks or to select a project that should be completed first.
Define and track key performance metrics throughout the project lifecycle to ensure goals are being met and to identify areas needing improvement.
Create a formal document that will be signed by the client to specify and fix the scope.
Inform the client that the current budget is insufficient to complete all project features. Ask for possibilities to increase the budget. Good luck!
Inform the client that the estimated duration is insufficient to complete all project features. Ask for possibilities to extend the deadline. Good luck!
Implement a document management system to organise, track, and version control project documents, ensuring all stakeholders have access to the latest information.
Pause work on parallel projects and reassign resources to address critical tasks on this project.
Instead of adhering strictly to the initial project plan, adjust plans at the start of each iteration (sprint) based on new insights and priorities.
Inform the client that the estimated duration is not sufficient to complete all project features. Discuss options to extend the deadline. Good luck!
Inform the client that the current budget is not enough to complete all project features. Discuss options to increase the budget. Good luck!
Inform the client that the estimated duration and budget are insufficient to complete all project features. Discuss options to adjust the project scope. Good luck!
Involve clients and customers in design sessions to ensure their needs and expectations are met.
Specify project requirements and features in the contract to establish clear boundaries and minimize the risk of scope creep.
Set a maximum duration for tasks to ensure no single task exceeds 10% of the project's total duration.
Organize training sessions to develop necessary skills and competencies among team members.
Organize activities to enhance team cohesion and morale, fostering better collaboration and communication.
Establish clear and consistent communication with all stakeholders to ensure alignment and address concerns promptly.
Hire an expert to acquire missing skills or competencies.
Organize regular meetings to inform project stakeholders, report the current status of the work, and get feedback.
Set time limitations for meetings (15 minutes for daily meetings) and project iterations (1 or 2 weeks). Reduce the scope per iteration if needed.
Increase salary for all team members. Good luck!
Choose communication channels that the client prefers. Call them if needed.
Encourage team members to manage their own work and time effectively.
Actively involve stakeholders in the project process to ensure their needs and expectations are met.
With all team members, set rules on what to do with those who don't contribute, how to remind deadlines, and the accepted social norms (no romance, no drama, etc.).
With all team members, set rules on how to deal with conflicts (Discussion -> Written communication -> Mediation -> Compromise -> Voting).
Implement a process of continuous improvement to regularly assess and improve project practices and outcomes.
Ensure that senior staff members work together with junior staff so that if one of them leaves, the other can take over.
Replace underperforming team members or restructure the team to better align with project goals.
Terminate the employment of problematic team members to eliminate disruptions.
In times of crisis, hold meetings to motivate the team to work harder and find solutions.
Implement short project iterations to quickly identify and address issues.
Support team members in achieving their full potential and improving performance through coaching and mentoring.
Implement disciplinary measures to address poor performance or behavior.
Make the organization as flat as possible and trust team members' self-regulatory and management abilities.
Involve team members in the management decisions.
Organize a strategy workshop to reinforce company values and business objectives.
Host a pizza party to boost team morale.
Parties, obligations, conditions, requirements, deliverables, etc., should be clearly and unambiguously defined.
Engage legal services to ensure all contractual obligations are met and to manage legal risks.
Set a fixed price for the entire project with the client.
Set up an hourly rate for the project.
Get insurance for the project.
Ensure that sensitive information is shared only with authorized parties.
Regularly review contracts to ensure compliance and address any issues promptly.
Register your trademark to make your services more visible and attractive.
Hire a subcontractor to complete a job where you have no competencies or resources or time to learn, or that is, in general, too risky. Good luck!
Hire a lawyer.
Expand to other countries to reduce the local market risks (saturated market, high production cost, expensive currency, etc.). Good luck!
Try convincing politicians how dangerous a new law is to the economy and their popularity. Good luck!
Purchase financial instruments like futures, options, or swaps to protect your project from currency fluctuation and other monetary risks. Good luck!
Ensure that the team can continue operating during and after a disruptive event. Share trust to promote self-regulation and knowledge sharing within the team.
Make donations to political parties to gain favor and influence policy decisions. Good luck!
Examine the organizationâ€™s information systems infrastructure, policies, and procedures to identify vulnerabilities. Make corrections.
Form strategic partnerships with other organizations to enhance capabilities and share risks.
Organize a series of crisis communication initiatives to explain to team members why they have to work harder and faster for less money.
Launch a public relations campaign to improve the public image and perception of the project or company.
Create and implement guidelines to improve the sustainability of the project outcome and make the process environmentally friendly.
Enter politics, get elected, and change the law threatening your business. Good luck!
Pay whatever is necessary to resolve the issue or mitigate the risk.
